facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 182 of 1964 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 182 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 20, 1959 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 325 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1959, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 325 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellants claiming to be descendants of former ruling chiefs in Hoshangabad and Nimar Districts of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claiming to be the descen- dants of former ruling chiefs in the Hoshangabad and Nimar Districts of Madhya Pradesh applied under the Central

facts.text: Appellants applied under Central Provinces and Berar Revocation of Land Revenue Exemptions Act, 1948 for grant of money or pension.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claiming to be the descen- dants of former ruling chiefs in the Hoshangabad and Nimar Districts of Madhya Pradesh applied under the Central Provinces and Berar Revocation of Land Revenue Exemptions Act, 1948,

facts.text: Appellants held estates as Jahgirdars, Maufidars and Ubaridars enjoying exemption from land revenue of Rs. 27,828-5-0 yearly.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants held estates in the two districts on favourable terms as Jahgirdars Maufidars and Ubaridars, and enjoyed an exemption from payment of land revenue amounting in the aggregate to Rs. 27,828-5-0 yearly.

facts.text: Act made estates liable to land revenue from year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: By that Act, every estate, mahal, village or land which was exempted from the payment of the whole or part of land revenue by special grant of, or companytract with the Crown, or under the provision of any law or rule for the time being in force or in pursuance of any other instrument was after the appointed date made liable to land revenue from the year 1948-49,

facts.text: Appellants applied to Deputy Commissioner who forwarded to State Government.

anchor.surface_text: They applied to the Deputy Commissioner, who forwarded their application to the State Government.

facts.text: State Government by order No. 993 XVI-4 dated April 26, 1955 rejected petition without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government by its order No. 993 XVI- 4, dated April 26, 1955 rejected their petition. No reasons are companytained in that order.

facts.text: Appellants filed petition in Madhya Pradesh High Court under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari to quash State Government order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon filed a petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the State Government.

facts.text: Petitioners contended rejection without reasons amounted to no decision and improper exercise of power under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: In that LlSup./65-18 petition they companytended that the, rejection of their petition by the State Government without giving any reasons amounted to numberdecision at all and was an improper and illegal exercise of the power vested in the State Government by s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: State Government contended appellants were not descendants of former ruling chief and exercise of power proper.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government resisted the petition by companytending that the appellants were number descendants of any former ruling chief and further that the exercise of the power by the State Government was proper and legal.

facts.text: High Court Full Bench disposed petition holding power under s.5 discretionary, petition incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The petition in the High Court was heard and disposed of by a Full Bench. The learned Chief Justice, who delivered the judgment on behalf of the Full Bench held that the State Government was number companypelled to grant either money or pension because the exercise of the power under s. 5 was discretionary and the petition, therefore was incompetent.

facts.text: High Court did not go into other questions.

anchor.surface_text: No other question was gone into by the High Court even though a suit is barred under the provisions of the Act and a petition under Art. 226 would appear to be the only remedy

facts.text: Section 5 provides for applications to Deputy Commissioner for award of grant or money or pension, forwarded to Provincial Government which may pass orders.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 then provides as follows - Awards of money grants or pension. Any person adversely affected by the provisions of section 3 may apply to the Deputy Commissioner of the district for the award of a grant or money or pension. The Deputy Commissioner shall forward the application to the Provincial Government, which may pass such orders as it deems fit.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.5(3) mandatory if applicant is descendant of former ruling chief and lost exemption.

anchor.surface_text: The word may in s. 5 3  must be interpreted as mandatory when the companyditions precedent, namely, the existence of a religious, charitable or public institutions which ought to be companytinued or of the descendants of a ruling chief, is established.

facts.text: State Government order of April 26, 1955 gives no reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether Government was justified in making the order of April 26, 1955 ? That order gives numberreasons at all.

facts.text: Appellants do not seem to have been heard at all by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The Act lays upon the Government a duty which obviously must be performed in a judicial manner. The appellants do number seem to have been heard at all.

facts.text: Rules framed under s.8 for dealing with applications under s.5(1).

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with this question we may also refer to the rules which have been framed under S. 8 of the Act. These rules, were made for dealing with applications received under S. 5 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Suit barred under provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: No other question was gone into by the High Court even though a suit is barred under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: High Court rejected petition at threshold on interpretation of s.5(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number go into any other question at all because it rejected the petition at the threshold on its interpretation of S. 5 3 .

holdings.text: The word may in s. 5(3) must be interpreted as mandatory when the conditions precedent, namely, the existence of a religious, charitable or public institutions which ought to be continued or of the descendants of a ruling chief, is established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.5 read harmoniously distinguishes general discretion under sub-s.(2) from obligation under sub-s.(3) for special categories; rules under s.8 require additional enquiries confirming special treatment; 'may' becomes obligatory per Maxwell on statutes when for benefit of others and conditions fulfilled.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in thinking that the third sub-section also like the second conferred an absolute discretion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was in error in thinking that the third sub- section also like the second companyferred an absolute discretion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-ss.(2) and (3) operate differently; sub-s.(2) for general applications, sub-s.(3) imposes duty if conditions met; absolute discretion in (2) does not render (3) nugatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since suit barred by s.6, administrative power under s.5 partakes quasi-judicial character requiring audi alteram partem and reasoned orders; cites Hari Nagar Sugar Mills precedent.

holdings.text: A petition under Art. 226 would appear to be the only remedy in case the State Government failed to comply with the terms of the Act, or acted in an illegal manner.

anchor.surface_text: No other question was gone into by the High Court even though a suit is barred under the provisions of the Act and a petition under Art. 226 would appear to be the only remedy in case the State Government failed to companyply with the terms of the Act, or acted in an illegal manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 bars civil suits; Art.226 available to challenge illegal or improper exercise of power under Act, especially discretionary powers turned obligatory.

holdings.text: The contention that powers under the Act are discretionary with no remedy by writ under Art. 226 cannot be supported.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.5 creates enforceable obligation in sub-s.(3); writ lies for failure to comply or illegal action as suit barred.
